Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my phone buzzing with a message from Sister Amina: “If you have a moment, I’d love to talk. Things have been heavy lately.” As the imam, I knew my role was to be available, to offer guidance and a listening ear. But just as I started to reply, my mother entered the room, her face drawn and tired. “You haven’t asked about your father in days,” she said quietly. Guilt pricked at me. I was supposed to check in, to be the daughter who noticed when things weren’t right at home. My parents needed me to be present, to ask, “Is everything okay?” and truly listen. Yet, the community expected me to be available too, to offer comfort and wisdom whenever needed. I felt pulled in two directions, my heart aching with the weight of both responsibilities. I looked at my mother, then at my phone, torn between the needs of my family and the needs of my community, unsure which call to answer first.
